ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Close reading, the ability to talk for an entire class about one or two specific passages, analytic writing (and how to approach it creatively), and a greater understanding on how people of different backgrounds view these iconic texts.
I developed very strong close-reading and writing skills, definitely can analyze each work and find meaning in the mundane in this overall very well-taught course.

I became a stronger writer as I bettered my close reading skills. My thesis writing developed as did my logical flow between papers. Alongside the improvement in my writing, which was facilitated by Professor Soles' constructive and helpful feedback, we discussed the themes of memory, nature, meaning, knowledge and more through the array of texts we read in DS literature. I felt consistently supported and challenged in seminar and in my essays.
better attention to form of language and pattern recognition in texts

I think that, generally speaking, DS literature really opened my eyes to a completely new (and very, very wonderful) way of looking at literature. While in high school, it was all about discussing certain broad themes, this year, I learned about how awesome and valuable close reading can be as a means to understanding a text. I think that DS lit has definitely demanded (as well as allowed for) a certain amount of creativity more than any of my other DS classes; I felt like I was able to look at a text and actually come up with something new and entirely my own!
My writing skills and critical thinking abilities improved tremendously.

I improved my academic analytical writing. I gained an attentiveness to blindness, color, consciousness, nostalgia, romanticism vs. rationalism, and meta-textuality in fiction and poetry. I gained a deeper understanding of myself as an artist, creator, and human.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Soles was my favorite professor of my entire first year at Yale. Not only was he incredibly passionate and knowledgable about the subject material, he truly cared about each and every one of us. He always strived to make class fun and interesting (even in his paper prompts, which included a series about a magical genie) and understood the various unique challenges this year presented both academically and mentally. He hosted a space for us to be together in the wake of tragedy and adapted whenever we needed a break. I felt particularly attached to this class and always looked forward to discussions rather than dreading getting on a zoom. I also felt that Professor Soles connected each of the pieces together even whenever I felt as if the connection between each of the works on the syllabus didn't seem to feel cohesive. He was also very flexible on submission times on papers, which took some of the pressure off and helped me to actually spend more time on each paper. 

Weaknesses: Overall DS gripes (lots of works, not enough time, large workload, still a considerable lack of diversity) were persistent. I also do not think that a timed exam (and this goes for all three classes) is a great way to measure our learning in this course. For example, (although I have yet to take the exam) our exam will be writing one or two essays in a three hour period. Considering we do not use timed writing anywhere within this course, I feel as if it is not an accurate measure of our knowledge. In addition, I felt as if this semester's works did not feel super connected. Last semester, there was an intense focus on greek tragedy, ancient life, religion/belief etc. This semester's connection was not as obvious and sometimes felt random (although like I stated above I think that Soles did an excellent job of trying to establish those connections). None of the weaknesses have to do with Soles as a professor.

strengths - amazing staff, great content, insightful discussions
weaknesses - workload, definitely became difficult to manage at times

Strengths: Although the readings were heavy (as per the nature of DS) my section drew connections across the curriculum routinely so it felt as if the texts were in a conversation with one another which helped ameliorate the breadth of the syllabus. The feedback I got from my professor was in depth and constructive; I felt that I was able to grow as a writer and thinker. My close reading skills became much stronger and my professor routinely incorporated poetry into our class which often sparked new insights into a theme we were discussing. The seminar environment in my section was vibrant, supportive, and engaging despite the virtual format - so much so that we joked that the world wasn't quite ready for our section to meet in person because of the energy and enthusiasm of our discussions. I also found myself more engaged and interested in the literature spring syllabus with Don Quixote, Racine, To The Lighthouse, and Omeros.
Weaknesses: At times the pacing was fast and the reading heavy, however this is true for the style of DS. Literature was my favorite track of DS both semesters so I do not have as many DS literature specific weaknesses.
great books, not a lot of time - typical of DS
I'm not sure there really were any weaknesses. I thought the course was wonderful, and I enjoyed it greatly.
This course is excellent. Professor Soles is an amazing teacher, and I greatly enjoyed class dicussions.

Weaknesses: Not enough time to read all the texts assigned; such long readings!!

Strengths: Fascinating, beautiful texts; wonderful instructor; excellent writing advice and office hours

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel as if DS courses were much easier to learn in and most likely remained the most true to the traditional experience. Of course, I speak with no experience of what Yale sans COVID looks like but this is just an observation.

My section with Professor Soles was the most lively section I have been in at Yale. His energy and dedication to checking in with us made everyone feel comfortable and encouraged to participate in seminar. Professor Soles was aware of the challenges of the semester and his awareness and consideration helped with the difficulties of the virtual semester as he offered extra time at the end of class for us to chat and discuss.
DS in general made great use of the online medium. I thought the discussion posts were especially effective.
I thought both virtual lectures and seminars went fairly well - seminars would obviously be better in person.
I think this course was as good as it could have been considering the virtual circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend Professor Soles and his section to anyone interested in DS. DS as a program was very rewarding and I met some awesome people through it; however, it is a very tailored program taste wise and I would only recommend it to someone interested in its material and someone who doesn't mind a large amount of reading/writing.

100% yes! The strengths of this course and the knowledge that it imparts on you is such a great reward, and even though I'm not majoring in humanities I feel like I have grown so much and have been armed with the tools to be a better writer, scientist, and person.

YES!!! Prof Soles and Directed Studies in general are a stellar introduction to Yale and its wide assortment of professors, subjects, and expertise. This course was very interesting due to the creativity input.

Yes! If you are considering DS I found literature and H&P to be the most compelling tracks of DS especially in the spring semester. Professor Soles is an incredible professor and I felt supported, challenged, and engaged throughout the entire semester which helped me find my voice in seminar and helped me become a better writer. The texts in DS literature paired well with the texts in the fall and by the time we read Omeros it felt as if our class had come full circle - while acknowledging the ways literary traditions had changed and remained the same.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in receiving a broad overview of some of the most influential texts in the Western canon.
Absolutely - Prof. Soles is a fantastic & engaging teacher. even over zoom, I could tell how much he enjoyed teaching and sharing his excitement for the texts.

Yes! As with all DS classes, there is of course the caveat that you should only take it if you are genuinely interested in the subject matter. But for anyone who is, I found DS lit to be an extraordinarily rich experience, and I especially loved the works that we got to read second semester!
Definitely - everyone should take DS! Professor Soles is amazing and provides detailed feedback.
I would definitely recommend this course! It has been my favorite my whole time at Yale. Prof. Soles was a wonderful instructor and the texts were emotionally moving.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We were provided with a recorded lecture and then our seminars were held live through Zoom.
recorded lecture and discussion section (virtual)
Recorded weekly lecture
Directed Studies Literature met two times a week for a virtual seminar; alongside the seminar were weekly recorded lectures.
virtual lecture
Combination of a recorded lecture plus a virtual seminar
virtual lectures
1x weekly lecture, 2x weekly virtual seminar
